title: Riot, good job on Sion's new story.
body:
You guys managed to make League's closest thing to a mindless killing machine somewhat sympathetic. That's not an easy thing to do. Sion has gone from a joke, to a character that is not only meaningful and interesting on his own, but who has a story that has implications into the deepest aspects of Noxus.

I always felt that the subtext to Swain's story that hinted at a not wholly great guy(by Noxus standards) was kind of glossed over after he became high-general. But this story and his treatment of Sion brings it back into new light. It also shows that the abrogation of the Noxus ideals(thanks to the Black Rose) are continuing even after the things that happened with the alliance with Zaun(if that stuff is still canon).

Anyways good job story team.

@Riot Opeli @Riotrunaan

replies.body:
The Sion storyline is an excellent example of staying faithful to the storyline of other characters involved while expanding the story of the main character.  I thought it was rather well done, and rewarded prior knowledge of lore.

People seem to misunderstand that the entirety of old lore has been wiped away, when in reality it's just the Institute that's been removed.  While it's not necessarily confirmed, I'm pretty sure we can say that anything that happened that didn't involve the Institute still happened, until proven otherwise.  Even events that did involve the Institute can be changed accordingly.  The pain is in the waiting.

Too bad it took the Freljord and Shurima lore culling to produce one champion worthy of the word "good."

When they fix what they've wronged, they will earn a pat on the back.

Braum is bad???
Braum wasn't a part of the massive retconning that happened. He was a new champion, and he's fine.

I actually don't mind most of that. The lore change was for the better for some champs. Olaf's and Sejuani's lore are way better. I'm not a huge fan of Gragas' new lore, but it's not horrible either. There are things I like and dislike about Trundle's new lore. But I definitely like it better than his old lore.

And I definitely think it was for the best to tie Nasus and Renekton into Shurima instead of being space gods. I don't really see a huge amount of problems with either lore-jobs.

As a Xerath main I DO MIND that since now the knowledge thirsty magus who ascended in order to not being limited by his human body has turned into Jafar playing with mirrors (the "complex" ritual was just a hall of mirrors). I wonder why when the outcry was for Viktor the Lore team changed it while for other characters they just hide behind the "oh but it's not complete" statement.

seriously I don't know why everyone thinks that Xerath is suddenly a guy who merely stole the ritual for getting to rule shurima?

I mean his Ascension is completely different than that of {{champion:268}}, {{champion:75}} &{{champion:58}} 
So he obviously modified it in some way,the sun disc(it is not just a hall of mirrors that he used,that is simply what was left of the sun disc) was merely a tool he needed to pull off his own version of ascension.

And who says that Xerath isn't the magus who" ascended in order to not being limited by his human body" anymore?We don't know anything about Xeraths motives for ascending,so there is nothing that says they are in any way different than old Xeraths motives.

I really hope that it's how you said and nothing has been revolutioned as much as I and others are seeing. What we got on which we can speculate is: Why {{champion:101}}  had such a different Ascension? 

First of all, he is the only mage who has ascended. The "3 of the desert" are warriors-like characters (even {{champion:75}}  to a small degree). Also, the main line seems to refer the Xerath's Ascension is corrupted but he /only source his quotes) is capable of seeing the very fabric of the Universe and nothing seems to contraddict that he would be omnipotent if not for the sarcophagus. 

What I fear though, is that we will be either left with nothing more in our hands (Shurima event has come to an end and many champions like {{champion:32}} haven't had a line in it) and it will be like this untill the next Shurima themed event/champion, or we'll be told by Riot: "This is all, get over it".

What I (and most of others) are asking is for some more light on it or either to recosnider it if this is all in the same way that happened for another champion ({{champion:112}}).

Well.. As far as I know, when Azir was about to ascend for the first time, Xerath interrupted Azir's Ascension ritual at the very beginning so he kind of Ascendened, in a very twisted way though, cause he only he started ascending after the ritual started.

Well, that's a silly way to say it, but think about it this way; someone (Azir) is going to have a tan in a tan machine, and like, before he even got to have any tan and time in the machine, his "friend" (Xerath) opens the machine, kicks him out and taking over it for himself, then getting an uncompleted tan. That a really stupid way to metaphor the story, but yeah, that's the best I got. XD :P

Hehe I got it you were good xD

But this is exactly why I am concerned about the state of Shurima (specifically Xerath) Lore. They just deleted 90% of it, replaced with 2-3 sneak peeks and called it done, leaving us with uncertanty about if the Old Lore still counts in any way or not.

I can't recall that they have ever called "Done" on the Shurima lore. I wanna believe that they know that these are definitely not done or anything. We do can tell that Riot might have plans to share more about stuff like Xerath's perspective on the Shurima event (they say that he had a reason to steal the Ascension from Azir and stuff like that), and yeah I know it might not be development, but I guess it something, and it might address more answers rather than raise more questions this time. :)

I still have hopes from the lore/narrative team though, and I at least find the new form of lore that is told from different perspectives (Vel'Koz's is first-person, Gnar's- well, it's more like a short story rather than a lore/biography- being told from Rengar's point of view, Heimerdinger's is his diary and Twitch's is a report for the police- or something like that). There are also rumors that Tryndamere (the Rioter) says that runes will be a big part of the lore soon, so I'm looking forward to something like that. :D

Trundle isn't the same troll though. Compare his old lore to new in-game presentation, especially voice lines (I don't care it's an ice troll), and it is just a different person. If they wanted a new champion to lead the trolls in the Freljord, make a new one. If you want Trundle to lead the trolls in the Freljord, make sure it's actually Trundle leading them. Worst thing is that the background actually came pretty close to being the same troll, though the in-game presentation is just horribly different.

This current state goes directly against preserving identities and I don't want to invest in lore in which my favorite characters could just be retconned and replaced with new ones next event.

Yeah Trundle is really the only champ where you can say that they basically deleted the old champ and made a new one.

Making someone new to lead the trolls was a no go,because if riot does a concept,they'll do it only once(so there will be no second troll,no second ice witch,no second war demon,no second sand mage,etc.),but I think they should have kept more of the old trundle.

But then again,old trundles ingame quotes were all about smashing the enemies face and he was a bit cocky already,so at least he kept that aspect.

Old Trundle was a troll constantly in pain and entirely willing to club anyone senseless from his in-game presentation, yes. The new Trundle is just plain power-hungry. He's just an evil mean troll trying to seize as much power as he can. This does not sound like the old Trundle, who was na√Øve but wanted his tribes admiration, he wanted to no longer be the bullied runt. When he took the curse and instead of getting their admiration he got their disgust for the curse they themselves once carried, he became cynical and stopped caring.

Parts of old Trundle are kept. It's just silly to see how close they got in the background, then how the details and the voice-over make it a new troll, as if they started with the right idea but got derailed.

If you need him to be king of trolls, he can't just shun his tribe. Why not make him protect his tribe out of a sense of duty yet loathe them for their weakness? You have this ambiguity back of Trundle who wants his tribes admiration but also kind of knows they're a bunch of small-minded *insert random insult*.

Also, I'm not sure we even know ice trolls existed before Trundle became one. They could've put just about anything in his place.

What appeals to me about the Trundle ret-con (and this is just me, not supposed to be a reason why it's better overall than the original, just why I happen to like it more) is the very realistic concept of a guy seizing power in his community because he believes it's the best way to save it, not necessarily only to achieve power for power's sake.  However, in doing so becomes enamored with it until that's all that matters to him, eclipsing his original good intentions.  

Eventually, this pursuit of power will go so far as to ironically bring down the community it was supposed to benefit.  In this specific case, that hasn't been outright stated but now the Freljord's trolls have essentially surrendered their autonomy to the Ice Witch, even if they don't know it yet.  By this point, that doesn't really matter to Trundle though.  He's seen the opportunity for even more power than he originally thought, and the fact that he pledged his whole people, who he had no right to speak for (heck, at the time he didn't even have the right to speak for his *own* tribe), to Lissandra shows just how far gone he was.   

That sort of change in a character (and yes, I'm making the assertion that there was a change and he wasn't initially like this) makes for a very compelling story, not entirely unlike the original, which has been stated earlier.  He set out to save his tribe, but ended up throwing them (and in the new story, many others) under the bus.  Yes, the character's personality is significantly changed but that can be attributed to the story differences such as his reason for betraying the other trolls - spite/revenge vs. personal gain. 

While both have merits, my personal preference goes to the troll chief usurper who had the audacity to name himself king.  Gotta admire that.

While I do agree it's a good story, I still think the character the same is one of the most important parts to keep when retconning if you care about the character in the first place. I don't think old Trundle would've just gone all power-hungry brute like the new one is. It doesn't seem like the same character.

I don't see this as a case of preferences, for this argument which one is better is irrelevant, it's a case of caring about your characters. Riot retconned a character and replaced him with a similar but different one.

I do like the interesting conflict that Sion seems to be going through. He seems vaguely aware that he's a mockery of the champion that he once was, but that awareness is constantly getting buried by his fanatic patriotism and his murderous tendencies. It's like a sane man trying to get out of an abandoned sanatorium full of insane mental patients.

I still wonder what they'll do regarding Urgot though. After going through explaining why Sion of all people is being resurrected, and how hard it was to get him semi-functional, I doubt that Urgot will be allowed to remain as a zombie.

They could just change the fact that Urgot is undead. Maybe make it so that he was so badly injured that they had to completely rework his body with machinery to keep him alive. I could see this angering some Urgot fans, but at the same time, would make him a bit more unique compared to Sion.

I'm a Urgot fan, and I'd be fine with that. What I like about him is the whole "Barely alive insult against nature, held together by crudely put together machinery and his own undying hatred for Garen and Demacia" aspect, rather than the fact that he came back to life.

If I were to redo his lore, maybe I'd have him start off as a devoted Noxian soldier wanting to do nothing but defend his country, and as he sustains grievous injuries and loses fellow soldiers to the Demacian advance, he slowly loses his mind and becomes a completely amoral monster, caring only to cause pain and torment to all Demacians, even innocent civilians. Culminating with Garen nearly slicing him in half for his crimes. Swain then decides that he could use so much focused, undying hatred in a man, and decides to stitch back his remains alongside a host of advanced Noxian weaponry, resulting in a being that lives in constant agony, but thrives in such agony, as it fills him with so many ideas on what to do with Demacians if he comes across them.

Well I am an Urgot fan and I think this could be a solution in some way.

However if you'd do that,then Urgot would loose this "frankensteins-monster"-feeling,so I'd say it is better to keep him undead.

Was thinking about that as well,but there are several possibilities:
1.Noxus got the needed necromancy-skills to truly revive someone(together with his/her mind) only after Sion had been reanimated already.(I think there was a quote from swain about how "Sion is too broken to be fixed")

2.It is because of the technology that was used to revive him and without them Urgot would have turned into a second Sion

3.The black rose intentionally revived sion this way to manipulate darkwill in some way.

Not really, the reason why Urgot needed to have so much technology sewn into him was because his body was so wrecked that he just wouldn't come back to life. And the process to revive Sion was deeply ingrained in how he died. I doubt that they could do the same thing with Urgot (Nor should they. A problem that Urgot and Sion have is that their origin stories were fairly similar to one another)

I also don't think the Sion in the game is quite the same Sion that killed Jarvan 1. The few shards of his original personality are too buried by the bloodthirsty psychopath that Swain put in it's place.

And I doubt that the Black Rose would intentionally botch Sion's resurrection. Just don't see the point in sabotaging any trust that Darkwill might have in them just yet.

yeah I know that the technology was needed because Urgot was too demolished,but that doesn't mean that it didn't help to preserve urgots mind,something that hasn't been done with Sion(alternatively there is always the possibility of a retcon)

And swain didn't make Sion into the bloddy psychopath that he is now,he was always like that after he got revived(before he was imprisoned he was called a mindless killing machine,that causes just as many casualities on its own side as it does on the enemy side,which was before swain knew anything about sion).
What swain did was merely making sion obedient to him.

And the black rose obviously wanted to weaken Borams position,giving him back his right-hand man would have helped him more than anything else.
